author: prince09
title: Airline boarding pass - Do you discard or post photos of it online?
text: I knew about the potential issues with boarding pass and somehow it always ends up in my backpack or pocket and not in the airport bin...beware! Quote: Chances are, you've already done it. You're at the airport, checked in and excited to be going on your plane journey to a new destination. So you snap a photo of your boarding pass, with your flight number and destination listed, and share it with your friends and followers on social media. If you're really lucky, you might be bragging about your seat number if it's particularly low. 1A means you're in the best seat in the plane, in either first or business class, but generally speaking a low number on your boarding pass is worth bragging about. But you should think twice before posting that photo online, a security expert warns. Btw, as If all the stupid selfies are not enough, who would take photos of boarding pass and post online for bragging...? Quote: A simple airline stub, picked out of a bin near Heathrow, led Steve Boggan to investigate a shocking breach of security This is the story of a piece of paper no bigger than a credit card, thrown away in a dustbin on the Heathrow Express to Paddington station. It was nestling among chewing gum wrappers and baggage tags, cast off by some weary traveller, when I first laid eyes on it just over a month ago
